Even for China’s police, this level of control is unprecedented. Tracking people so closely once required central government cooperation. Now, police are building their own trackers, and no court or agency has the power or willingness to stop it. https://t.co/LDXMtXK20M

The personal data collected by the Chinese government on millions of people is parked on servers unprotected by basic security measures, our investigation found. Middlemen and private contractors have wide access to even the most sensitive information.

The surveillance push gives police, who have taken a greater role in China under President Xi Jinping, a potent way to track criminals, as well as sympathizers of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movement, and ethnic minorities already being targeted by the government. https://t.co/pnWhP8IiUL

These tools can help police grab the identities of people walking down the street and find out who they're meeting with. The U.S. uses some of these tactics to track terrorists or drug lords. China wants to use it to track everybody: a blueprint for a digital totalitarian state.

Imagine a world in which police can track every single person, online and on the street, using facial recognition cameras, phone scanners, and fingerprint databases. China is building it. 
https://t.co/fyFwmYjoSx

@andrewkeh @lynseyaddario As her health worsened, Marieke Vervoort struggled. "I pray to die," she said. "But It’s so hard to say, ‘This is the day I want to go.’"

But she said she wanted her story to be told — of her life and her death, on October 22. She was 40 years old. https://t.co/0GpCPzyGkE

@andrewkeh @lynseyaddario Marieke Vervoort’s success opened doors: She traveled, checked items off her bucket list and won sponsors.

But her health soon deteriorated as the pain intensified. By mid-2017, she was openly addicted to morphine. Her friends became more like caretakers. https://t.co/XcGA3uL9Sj

@andrewkeh @lynseyaddario At the 2016 Paralympics, Marieke Vervoort told the world about her health after false reports said that she planned to kill herself after the competition.

She denied that — but forcefully defended her choice and called on more countries to allow doctor-assisted suicide. https://t.co/gGdwCu6v53

@andrewkeh @lynseyaddario Sports had long been Marieke Vervoort's outlet. But the option to pursue euthanasia, she said, let her thrive.

Within a few years, she achieved excellence in wheelchair sports. She won 4 medals, including a gold, at the Paralympic games and 3 golds at the world championships. https://t.co/QJsGU8N4Mz

@andrewkeh @lynseyaddario Doctors could never fully explain the disease that stole the use of Marieke Vervoort's legs and caused agonizing pain.

But, she said, her decision to pursue euthanasia turned her life around. 11 years passed until she decided, this year, she was ready to die. https://t.co/atVgp9sWdz

.@AndrewKeh and @LynseyAddario chronicled how Marieke Vervoort came to end her life as she suffered from a degenerative muscle disease.

What they saw was a top athlete taking control of her own destiny in an extraordinary fashion. https://t.co/J0Q5G6lcg7

She was a world-class athlete. A gold medal-winning Paralympian. And she wanted to die. 

We spent three years with Marieke Vervoort as she and her family wrestled with her decision to end her life. https://t.co/IK4qHf8k0B

@globaldan Minford's Class of 2000 started high school the year Purdue Pharma introduced OxyContin. By their senior year, painkillers were everywhere, in classrooms, school bathrooms, parties: "I told myself I was never going to do them. But kids were selling Oxys at school for $3 a pill."

Nearly 50 members of Minford High School's Class of 2000 shared with @globaldan how opioids have impacted their lives, families and community. Their stories shed new light on the epidemic's rise and spread over a generation. https://t.co/OqSZ5gONMY https://t.co/Gfxx5a9e8x

A former detainee at one of the camps described officials’ goal as imposing loyalty to China. https://t.co/PJQBpRWMpG

The directive orders camps to keep extensive records on every detainee, using a scoring system to determine whether detainees can be released — an implied threat aimed at silencing complaints.

At every moment, detainees must meet “disciplinary demands” or face punishment. https://t.co/wgb3TqCZXL

In one document, an official ordered strict measures to manage the camps: rigid control over how detainees spend their days and the recruiting of informants to spy on them. One passage details how to prevent escapes, in language similar to what’s used in guidelines for prisons. https://t.co/0AGQd1ilxn

The documents, obtained by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, reveal the punitive nature — pervasive surveillance, isolation from the world — of camps that China publicly calls job training centers and an effort against the pull of extremism. https://t.co/RO0ardk2YD

Juul now faces a growing pile of lawsuits from parents, school districts, counties and states. While it says it's refocused on public health, it's under scrutiny from U.S. regulators, who it must convince to let it stay on the market.

Read our full story: https://t.co/3l1Rq0CgSc

In the early days, Juul's packaging only listed nicotine in tiny type in the ingredients and did not have the warning labels it does now. That means some who are hooked didn't know what they were getting into. https://t.co/BykP3StcLd

The addictiveness and strength of Juul is no accident. The company set out to develop a way for its product to pack the same punch as a cigarette, delivering a nicotine level of 5%, up to 5 times more powerful than other e-cigarettes at the time. https://t.co/hfZBculRKB

Now 4 years later, Juul is a giant of e-cigarettes. It hit $1 billion in sales in 2018, and at the end of last year, was valued at $38 billion, more than Ford Motor Company.

But that growth also shows how addictive its product has proven, with smokers and young people alike. https://t.co/6IxQE5O4of

In a 2015 board meeting, which has not been previously reported, Juul's chief operating officer said he had advised the company to slow down and take the time needed to fix supply chain problems and manufacturing defects. He was fired the next day. https://t.co/kSgZmmggbw

Under pressure from investors, Juul's own marketing diverged from its stated public health mission. It geared ads to those in their 20s and early 30s, a generation with historically low smoking rates.

Even some Juul employees were confused as young people flocked to the product. https://t.co/isBRGixeBW

Juul said its e-cigarette was meant to be a safer tobacco alternative — not hook a younger generation on nicotine.

But the reality inside Juul was different. Here's how decisions it made planted the seeds of a public health crisis that's hooked millions. https://t.co/jsCKirOLMY

@theintercept We hope you’ll take the time to read our full story on how Iran came to dominate the political and military spheres in Iraq. But if you don’t have time now, here are the main takeaways from the hundreds of leaked documents. https://t.co/LiW5WlFMJl

@theintercept The Times and @TheIntercept verified the authenticity of the roughly 700 pages of #irancables but don't know who leaked them. The source declined to meet with a reporter but said they wanted to “let the world know what Iran is doing in my country Iraq.” https://t.co/9hl83ariMP

@theintercept The files largely confirm what was already known about Iran’s grip on Iraqi politics, but underscore how long Iran has had the upper hand in Iraq — the result of proximity, a shared faith and the many weapons — outmaneuvering the U.S. in the contest for influence.

@theintercept This portrait of Iran's influence in Iraq is all the more striking at a time of heightened tensions between the U.S. and Iran. And in Iraq itself, violent street protests have erupted over what some say is egregious Iranian meddling in their affairs. https://t.co/9hl83ariMP

@theintercept According to the reports, many of Iraq's foremost political, military, and security officials have had secret relationships with Tehran, including Prime Minister Adil Abdul Mahdi. A 2014 cable described Abdul Mahdi, then oil minister, as having a "special relationship" with Iran. https://t.co/YzN5CWmmnW

@theintercept The leak contains hundreds of cables sent by MOIS, Iran's version of the CIA, from 2014 to 2015 and details work by Iranian spies to co-opt Iraq’s leaders, pay Iraqi agents working for the U.S. to switch sides and infiltrate every aspect of political, economic and religious life. https://t.co/GiVo9SdTB0

We hope you'll take the time to read our full investigation on the leak of Chinese government documents and the state's mass detention of Muslims. But if you don't have time now, here are 5 takeaways. https://t.co/kqzG6vE8Pf

Read our full story of how more than 400 pages of internal Chinese documents provide an unprecedented look — in Chinese officials' own words — at the state's secretive crackdown on Muslims in Xinjiang https://t.co/xTk7vzQ9kB

We’ve published in full one of the documents that show how Chinese officials in Xinjiang planned to explain to Muslims and others affected by the crackdown that their parents or families were being detained in camps. Read it here: https://t.co/7ySRlJxRW0

At least one official resisted, the documents show. Wang Yongzhi released more than 7,000 inmates — and was then detained, stripped of power and prosecuted.

He was made an example of publicly. But the government hid the fact of his resistance in an internal report. https://t.co/lqiJ1rxHrN

The documents also show how a hard-liner named Chen Quanguo used fear to mobilize officials to carry out mass detentions. “Round up everyone who should be rounded up.”

New security controls and a drastic expansion of indoctrination camps followed. https://t.co/RHKfpJTNxH

In private, Chinese leaders displayed a fixation with radical Islam that went beyond their public remarks. The documents show they worried about terrorist attacks abroad, and President Xi urged officials to study Americans' response to the Sept. 11 attacks. https://t.co/FS2YqAvLwk

Chinese officials were concerned enough about anger due to their campaign, the documents show, that they distributed a chillingly bureaucratic guide for answering questions from those whose relatives disappeared, saying they were receiving training for "their own good" https://t.co/RZVuaPVu1A

Publicly, Chinese officials say the Xinjiang camps provide job training. But privately, the documents show, they used words like "virus," "infected" and "eradicate" to justify mass detentions and plotted how they would manage and intimidate families that were torn apart. https://t.co/UaDbh4CCna

The documents — one of the most significant leaks from inside China's Communist Party in decades — reveal secret speeches by President Xi Jinping laying the groundwork for a crackdown that put a million or more Muslim minorities into camps. "Show absolutely no mercy," he said. https://t.co/JkBUiii64R

China has detained up to a million Muslims, a campaign it calls a benevolent and routine effort against the pull of extremism. But 403 pages of Communist Party documents we obtained reveal how officials plotted to carry out a ruthless, coercive clampdown. https://t.co/s6Sa2GenA3

See the full timeline of how demonstrations that started over Hong Kong’s extradition proposal came to convulse the territory with increasingly violent protests, undermining President Xi Jinping’s reputation for unshakable control of China https://t.co/vmrz7A7fmE

October 1: Protesters clash with riot police in at least 9 districts as Beijing celebrates the 70th anniversary of Communist rule in China, turning Hong Kong into a battlefield. For the first time, a protester — an 18-year-old — is shot by police with a live round. https://t.co/QsXZwf066L

September 4: The Hong Kong government formally withdraws the extradition bill, leader Carrie Lam says, giving in to one of the protesters’ major demands but satisfying only one of the issues that had come to fuel the demonstrations. Protests continued the next weekend. https://t.co/8laf6bOb0x

August 31: On the 5th anniversary of China’s 2014 proposal to limit direct elections in Hong Kong, chaos returned. Demonstrators set fires to barricades and brawled with the police, who used water cannons loaded with blue dye, to mark them for later arrest. https://t.co/WP6P4K27lD

August 5: Furious at the police and government inaction, protesters tried to bring Hong Kong to a halt, holding a general strike, disrupting 200 flights and occupying shopping malls and blocking roads and rail lines. Police responded with tear gas and arrested scores of people. https://t.co/GB22RIMKfw

July 9: Hong Kong’s leader Carrie Lam says the bill that set off the demonstrations — which would allow extraditions to mainland China — is “dead.” But demonstrators were furious she didn't withdraw the bill completely — and they returned to the streets. https://t.co/vmrz7A7fmE https://t.co/6D2TUYsYJS

July 1: Thousands protested to mark the anniversary of Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty. But a smaller group stormed the Legislative Council, vandalizing the building. In graffiti, someone wrote, “It was the government who taught us that peaceful protest is useless.” https://t.co/KsR1KOKMyF

June 16: Angered by the police response, as many as 2 million people marched in defiance of the government, according to organizers’ estimates. They also started to demand an independent investigation into the use of force by the police. https://t.co/vmrz7A7fmE https://t.co/IYRsl7FzgM

June 12: 3 days after a million people took to the streets, protesters surrounded the Hong Kong Legislative Council. They threw bricks, bottles and umbrellas. Police answered with pepper spray, batons and tear gas, a sharp escalation in violence. https://t.co/vmrz7A7fmE https://t.co/TGePK4pRHq

Of the 26 mass shootings we examined:
– None of them went unsolved. In every case, the suspect was male. 
– In about half of the cases, suspects had a family or romantic tie to at least one victim.
– Children died in 11 of the mass shootings. None happened at a school.

Mass shootings keep happening in the U.S.
